sen.j: 青山 忠裕（あおやま ただひろ（ただやす）、明和5年5月8日 (旧暦)（1768年6月22日） - 天保7年3月27日 (旧暦)（1836年5月12日））は、江戸時代の大名、老中。
sen.e: Tadahiro AOYAMA (June 22, 1768-May 12, 1836) was daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in Edo period.
Tadahiro AOYAMA (June 22, 1768-May 12, 1836) was daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in Edo period.
Tadahiro AOYAMA (June 22, 1768 - May 12, 1836) was daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and roju (member of shogun's council of elders) in Edo period.
sen.cmt: スペース補足しました。

sen.j: 丹波国篠山藩第4代藩主。
sen.e: The fourth lord of the Sasayama Domain in Tanba Province
The fourth lord of the Sasayama Domain in Tanba Province
The fourth lord of the Sasayama Domain in Tanba Province

sen.j: 青山家宗家10代。
sen.e: The tenth soke (the head family or house) of Aoyama family.
The tenth soke (the head family or house) of Aoyama family.
The tenth soke (the head family or house) of Aoyama family.

sen.j: 2代藩主青山忠高の3男。
sen.e: The third son of Tadataka AOYAMA; the second lord.
The third son of Tadataka AOYAMA; the second lord.
The third son of Tadataka AOYAMA; the second lord.

sen.j: 母は鵜飼氏。
sen.e: His mother was a member of the Ukai clan.
His mother was a member of the Ukai clan.
His mother was a member of the Ukai clan.

sen.j: 正室は土井利剛の娘（土井利里の養女）。
sen.e: His lawful wife was the daughter of Toshikata DOI (the adopted daughter of Toshisato DOI).
His lawful wife was the daughter of Toshikata DOI (the adopted daughter of Toshisato DOI).
His lawful wife was the daughter of Toshikata DOI (the adopted daughter of Toshisato DOI).

sen.j: 子に青山忠良（四男）、青山幸哉（七男）、日野資敬、娘（桜井松平忠誨正室のち松浦曜継室）。
sen.e: His children were Tadanaga AOYAMA (the forth son), Yukishige AOYAMA (the seventh son), Sukenori HINO (daughter. The lawful wife of Tadataka SAKURAIMATSUDAIRA, later the second wife of Terasu MATSURA).

His children were Tadanaga AOYAMA (the forth son), Yukishige AOYAMA (the seventh son), Sukenori HINO (daughter. The lawful wife of Tadataka SAKURAIMATSUDAIRA, later the second wife of Terasu MATSURA).

His children were Tadanaga AOYAMA (the forth son), Yukishige AOYAMA (the seventh son), Sukenori HINO, and a daughter (the lawful wife of Tadanori SAKURAI MATSUDAIRA, later the second wife of Terasu MATSURA).
sen.cmt: , and a daughter (the lawful wife～と訂正しました。松平忠誨→Tadanori MATSUDAIRAに訂正しました。

sen.j: 官位は従四位下、因幡国守、下野国守。
sen.e: His ranks were Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), Inaba-no-kuni-no-kami (the governor of Inaba Province), Shimotsuke no kuni no kami (the governor of Shimotsuke Province).
His ranks were Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), Inaba-no-kuni-no-kami (the governor of Inaba Province), Shimotsuke no kuni no kami (the governor of Shimotsuke Province).
His ranks were Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), Inaba no kuni no kami (the governor of Inaba Province), Shimotsuke no kuni no kami (the governor of Shimotsuke Province).
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除、スペース補足しました。

sen.j: 天明5年（1785年）、兄で3代藩主の青山忠講が嗣子なく21歳で没したため、家督を継ぐ。
sen.e: In 1785, Tadatsugu AOYAMA, his elder brother; the third lord, passed away at the age of 21 years old without a heir; so he took over the reigns of family.
In 1785, Tadatsugu AOYAMA, his elder brother; the third lord, passed away at the age of 21 years old without a heir; so he took over the reigns of family.
In 1785, Tadatsugu AOYAMA, his elder brother; the third lord, passed away at the age of 21 years old without a heir; so he took over the reigns of family.

sen.j: 忠裕は、寺社奉行、若年寄、大坂城代、京都所司代と、およそ幕閣の登竜門とされるポストを残らず勤め、文化 (元号)元年（1804年）老中に起用され30年以上勤めるなど、文化文政期の幕閣の中心人物として活躍した。
sen.e: Tadahiro took an active role as a key person of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate in Bunka-Bunsei period; he was engaged in all the posts which were deemed as a gateway to the cabinet officials of the Shogunate such as jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines), wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu), Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle), Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy), and served as roju (member of shogun's council of elders) for 30 years after he was employed in 1804.

Tadahiro took an active role as a key person of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate in Bunka-Bunsei period; he was engaged in all the posts which were deemed as a gateway to the cabinet officials of the Shogunate such as jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines), wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu), Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle), Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy), and served as roju (member of shogun's council of elders) for 30 years after he was employed in 1804.

Tadahiro took an active role as a key person of the cabinet officials of the Shogunate in Bunka-Bunsei period; he was engaged in all the posts which were deemed as a gateway to the cabinet officials of the Shogunate such as jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines), wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu), Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle), Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy), and served as roju (member of shogun's council of elders) for 30 years after he was employed in 1804.

sen.j: 老中在任中、相馬大作事件の裁判や、桑名藩、忍藩、白河藩の三方国替えなどを担当した記録がある。
sen.e: It is recorded that he took charge of the trial of Incident of Daisaku SOMA, replacement of three provinces; the Kuwana Domain, the Oshi Domain, Shirakawa Domain during his service as roju.
It is recorded that he took charge of the trial of Incident of Daisaku SOMA, replacement of three provinces; the Kuwana Domain, the Oshi Domain, Shirakawa Domain during his service as roju.
It is recorded that he took charge of the trial of Incident of Daisaku SOMA, replacement of three provinces; the Kuwana Domain, the Oshi Domain, Shirakawa Domain during his service as roju.

sen.j: 天保6年（1835年）隠居し、家督を四男の忠良に譲る。
sen.e: He retired in 1835, and let Tadanaga (the forth son) take over the reigns of family.
He retired in 1835, and let Tadanaga (the forth son) take over the reigns of family.
He retired in 1835, and let Tadanaga (the forth son) take over the reigns of family.

sen.j: 翌天保7年（1836年）没した。
sen.e: He died in 1836.
He died in 1836.
He died in 1836.

tit.cmt: ピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 毎年春と秋に本所回向院で将軍臨席で大相撲があった。
sen.e: Every spring and autumn, a grand sumo tournament in the presence of shogun was held at Honjo-ecoin Temple.
Every spring and autumn, a grand sumo tournament in the presence of shogun was held at Honjo-ecoin Temple.
Every spring and autumn, a grand sumo tournament in the presence of shogun was held at Honjoeko-in Temple.

sen.j: 篠山藩の力士は毎年、真っ先に負け続きで忠裕はたいそう不機嫌であった。
sen.e: Tadahiro was grouchy during the sumo tournament every year because the sumo wrestlers of the Sasayama Domain lost the game at the head.
Tadahiro was grouchy during the sumo tournament every year because the sumo wrestlers of the Sasayama Domain promptly lost from the very beginning.
Tadahiro was grouchy during the sumo tournament every year because the sumo wrestlers of the Sasayama Domain promptly lost from the very beginning.

sen.j: 文政3年（1820年）春場所のある日、大地山平左衛門、波賀野山源之丞、飛の山三四郎、黒田山兵衛、曽地山左近、小田中清五郎、須知山道観、須知山道観という八名の力士が篠山から出て来て、相撲を取らせてくださいといった。
sen.e: One day during the spring tournament, eight sumo wrestlers; 大地山平左衛門, 波賀野山源之丞, 飛の山三四郎, 黒田山兵衛, 曽地山左近, 小田中清五郎, 須知山道観, 須知山道観, came out of Sasayama, and they asked for their entry into the tournament.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。地山平左衛門, 波賀野山源之丞, 飛の山三四郎, 黒田山兵衛, 曽地山左近, 小田中清五郎, 須知山道観, 須知山道観→読み方不明のため原文のままとしています。
sen.e: One day during the spring tournament, eight sumo wrestlers; 大地山平左衛門, 波賀野山源之丞, 飛の山三四郎, 黒田山兵衛, 曽地山左近, 小田中清五郎, 須知山道観, 須知山道観, came out of Sasayama, and they asked for their entry into the tournament.

In 1820, one day during the spring tournament, eight sumo wrestlers; Heizaemon OCHIYAMA, Gennojo HAGANOYAMA, Sanshiro TOBINOYAMA, Yamabe KURODA, Sakon SOJIYAMA, Seigoro KODANAKA, Dokan SHICHIYAMA and Matashiro YORITAKA, came out of Sasayama, and they asked for their entry into the tournament.
sen.cmt: 地名より推測して表記しました、大地山平左衛門→Heizaemon OCHIYAMA波賀野山源之丞→Gennojo HAGANOYAMA飛の山三四郎→Sanshiro TOBINOYAMA黒田山兵衛→Yamabe KURODA曽地山左近→Sakon SOJIYAMA小田中清五郎→Seigoro KODANAKA須知山道観→Dokan SHICHIYAMA頼尊又史郎→Matashiro YORITAKA (原文には同名が繰り返しとなっていますが、調査の結果8人目は「頼尊又史郎」のようです。）In 1820, 補足しました。

sen.j: 忠裕が出場させたところ、全員が勝った。
sen.e: After he allowed them to join the game, all of them won.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: After he allowed them to join the game, all of them won.
After he allowed them to join the game, all of them won.

sen.j: 喜んだ忠裕が褒美を取らせようとしたところ全員どこにもいなかった。
sen.e: Tadahiro was so pleased that he was going to reward them, but they were gone.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Tadahiro was so pleased that he was going to reward them, but they were gone.
Tadahiro was so pleased that he was going to reward them, but they were gone.

sen.j: 後で調べたが篠山にはそんな名前の力士はいない、ただ篠山領のお稲荷さんがまつられている地名ということがわかり、それぞれの稲荷神社へ感謝のためにのぼり絵馬を奉納したという。
sen.e: Later on, it was identified that sumo wrestlers with such names didn't exist and those names are the names of places where Inari (god of harvests) were worshipped; he worshipped all of the Inari shrines to dedicate Ema (a votive horse tablet) to them.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Later on, it was identified that sumo wrestlers with such names didn't exist and those names are the names of places where Inari (god of harvests) were worshipped; he worshipped all of the Inari shrines to dedicate Ema (a votive horse tablet) to them.

Later on, it was identified that sumo wrestlers with such names didn't exist and those names are the names of places where Inari (god of harvests) were worshipped; he worshipped all of the Inari shrines to dedicate Ema (a votive horse tablet) to them.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 忠裕は特産物の一旦として王地山窯を発祥させた。
sen.e: Tadahiro originated Mount Oji ceramic as a part of local specialty.
Tadahiro originated Mount Oji ceramic as a local specialty.
Tadahiro originated Mount Oji ceramic as a local specialty.

sen.j: 文政元年（1818年）、藩領の王地山（篠山市河原町）に、京焼の陶工欽古堂亀祐（きんこどう・かめすけ）を招いて始めた藩窯で、中国の青磁、染付、赤絵を主とした磁器窯である。
sen.e: It is a ceramic ware mainly including celadon, dyed ceramics, Akae ware (ceramics with red paintings) from China which was originated at Mount Oji ceramic (present day Kawaramachi, Sasayama City) of the feudal domain as the ceramic of the domain in 1818 under the instructions of Kamesuke Kinkodo (Kyoto ceramic) who was invited.

It is a ceramic ware that mainly included celadon, dyed ceramics, Akae ware (ceramics with red paintings) from China which was originated at Mount Oji ceramic (present day Kawaramachi, Sasayama City) of the feudal domain as the ceramic of the domain in 1818 under the instructions of Kamesuke Kinkodo (Kyoto ceramic) who was invited.

It is a ceramic ware that mainly included celadon, dyed ceramics, Akae ware (ceramics with red paintings) from China which was originated at Mount Oji ceramic (present day Kawaramachi, Sasayama City) of the feudal domain as the ceramic of the domain in 1818 under the instructions of Kamesuke KINKODO (Kyoto ceramic) who was invited.

sen.j: 経歴
sen.e: Career
Career
Career

sen.j: 1768年（明和5年） 生誕
sen.e: He was born in 1768
He was born in 1768
He was born in 1768

sen.j: 1785年（天明5年） 篠山藩襲封
sen.e: Inheritance of the territories of the Sasayama Domain
sen.cmt: 襲封をデータベースで検索したところ、Inheritation of the territories とありましたが正しくはInheritance of the territories と思われます。
sen.e: Inheritance of the territories of the Sasayama Domain
In 1785, inheritance of the territories of the Sasayama Domain

sen.j: 1793年（寛政5年） 8月24日 (旧暦)寺社奉行（～1796年11月29日 (旧暦)）
sen.e: jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) August 24, 1793-November 29, 1796 (in old calendar)
jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines) August 24, 1793-November 29, 1796 (in old calendar)
September 28, 1793 - December 27, 1796: jisha-bugyo (magistrate of temples and shrines)

sen.j: 1796年（寛政8年） 西丸若年寄
sen.e: Nishimaru wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu) in 1796
Nishimaru wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu) in 1796
In 1796, Nishi no maru (the western keep of a castle) wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu)
sen.cmt: 訂正、補足しました。西丸→Nishi no maru (the western keep of a castle)

sen.e: Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle) October 1, 1800-October 19, 1802 (in old calendar)
Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle) October 1, 1800-October 19, 1802 (in old calendar)
November 17, 1800 - November 14, 1802: Osaka jodai (the keeper of Osaka Castle)

sen.j: 1802年（享和2年） 11月14日 (旧暦)京都所司代（～1804年1月23日 (旧暦)）
sen.e: Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) November 14, 1802-January 23, 1804 (in old calendar)
Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy) November 14, 1802-January 23, 1804 (in old calendar)
December 8, 1802 - March 4, 1804: Kyoto shoshidai (The Kyoto deputy)

sen.j: 1804年（文化 (元号)元年） 1月23日 (旧暦)老中
sen.e: Roju (member of shogun's council of elders) on January 23, 1804
Roju (member of shogun's council of elders) on January 23, 1804
March 4, 1804: Roju (member of shogun's council of elders)

sen.j: 1827年（文政10年） 1万石加増、6万石。
sen.e: Sixty thousands Goku crop yields (ten thousands Goku crop yields added) in 1827
Sixty thousands Goku crop yields (ten thousands Goku crop yields added) in 1827
In 1827, Sixty thousands Goku crop yields (ten thousands Goku crop yields added)

sen.j: 1835年（天保6年） 5月6日 (旧暦)老中辞任。隠居。
sen.e: Resigned as Roju on May 6, 1835 (in old calendar), and then retired.
Resigned as Roju on May 6, 1835 (in old calendar), and then retired.
June 1, 1835: Resigned as Roju, and then retired.

sen.j: 1836年（天保7年） 3月27日、死去。
sen.e: He passed away on March 27, 1836.
He passed away on March 27, 1836.
He passed away on May 12, 1836.
